signatories.roles: Former Peyrin Student, Worked with Peyrin on Course Staff, EECS/CS Undergrad Student, UC Berkeley Undergrad Student
signatories.comment:
I had Peyrin as an instructor for CS 161, CS 188, and CS 168, and worked with Peyrin for 4 semesters as a TA for CS 188. Peyrin's contributions to CS at Berkeley are nothing short of a miracle for the department, and to be frank, losing Peyrin will be a disaster. The department needs to be made aware.

Never have I ever seen someone as devoted or hardworking as Peyrin. Myself and/or my friends have directly seen him:

- Sleep in Soda Hall after working long into the night
- With the help of a few TA's, grade an exam literally overnight, by staying up past midnight
- Answer so many students' Ed questions that he started to post them as invisible-to-students so that other TA's could copy-paste his responses and take the credit
- Bail out overflowing office hours queues when TA's were swamped--even though he wasn't officially teaching that class that semester
- Be actively working at 12AM on New Year's Day

Peyrin has the unique ability to run multiple classes smoothly in a way that absolutely no professor or head TA ever could. In every semester I've worked with him, he has been majorly involved in running logistics for at the bare minimum, 3 or 4 different courses, often without even officially being an instructor. No task is too menial or too complex for him--he isn't afraid to go print exams at 3 in the morning, but has the knowledge and experience to write exam questions and deal with far-reaching course policies.

While TA's and instructors certainly work hard, Peyrin is an incredible force multiplier and his loss would directly torpedo the effectiveness of, at minimum, 4 different key courses (CS 61B, CS 161, CS 188, CS 168). With less capacity to handle students in these classes, and with students less prepared and more stressed for follow-on courses, the effects will propagate throughout the entire department like a tsunami.

Any insinuation that Peyrin's activism or hunger strike have negatively impacted his teaching abilities and student learning is preposterous, because he's always done so much more than has been expected of him. Even if he was 1/2 as productive as he is, he would still be as effective as a particularly hardworking teaching professor--and leagues beyond many of my professors, to be honest.

I'll leave it to my peers to speak about other factors. But from a pedagogical standpoint, suspending Peyrin would be the biggest mistake the department could make.

In my time at Berkeley (CS + ISF BA, EECS MS), I learned about the IBM punch cards that enabled the holocaust, and it was ok for my professors to say "never again should our discipline be complicit in something like this." This was the absolute bare minimum of our "tech ethics" training. The AI and computing technologies being used to surveil Palestinians and mark them for death are most certainly built upon Berkeley innovations in computer vision, databases, etc. At the very least, then, now is the time for us computer scientists to recognize the evil our contributions are being used for and to stand against it. It is damning that the administration would choose to punish and silence the member of CS faculty with the greatest moral clarity around this, and I'm deeply ashamed of my alma mater. Furthermore, Peyrin’s comments regarding Palestine were made following class. The action against Peyrin seems aimed at limiting free speech and sanctioning a highly visible pro-Palestine voice in campus. Our job as STEM faculty is to encourage our colleagues and students to reckon with the ethical implications of science and technology. I see Peyrin’s actions as doing just that.

Palestine will be free and you will discarded in the dustbins of history.

Such a stain on UC Berkeley’s pathetic excuse for a reputation as “free speech university”, freedom of speech for WHO?! This is the most repressive hellscape of an institution I have ever attended. I feel nothing but shame to say I attended Cal.

As a historian who studies the history of science, technology, and medicine, I am concerned about the wide implication of the UC's indefensible choice to discipline and suspend Prof. Kao. My own research and scholarly discipline is predicated on the idea that science, technology, and medicine, are not neutral scientific enterprises. I teach undergrads-- frequently, those in the college of engineering and the new college of CS-- that science is a social process, and that the choices they make as scientists have profound historical, cultural, and ethical dimensions. UCVP Hermalin's letter is not merely an affront to academic freedom of speech. It also serves only to marginalize scholarship that affirms with Prof. Kao shared with his class: that being a scientist does not make you immune from ethical inquiry. My own ability to teach UC Berkeley undergrads is undermined by the insistence from the highest level of the university that there is no appropriate consideration of ethics or politics that can be allowed in the STEM classroom. It makes it actively more difficult to engage with students when University messaging positions STEM as neutral, empirical, and apolitical. Why would we want to send graduates into the world who are encouraged to dodge difficult questions about the impact they want their work to have in the world?

signatories.comment: My tata passed away before the start of the semester. I emailed all my professors/lecturers informing them I would be absent the first week. He is the only one who was genuine with condolences and even offered resources Incase the grief was too much to bare throughout the semester. I truly appreciate Peyrin and only have kind words to say. I cannot say the same for many of the other CS lecturers at UCB. The only thing he is guilty of is having courage and empathy. We have the freedom to protest and speech, but why is it no longer a right against a known genocide? These actions against Peyrin aren’t justified and simply wrong. He is a critical asset to the Computer Science department. Not many CS professors at CAL are meant to teach. Peyrin is the exception and should have been protected by this institution.

signatories.comment: Peyrin is the best lecturer I’ve had at UC Berkeley in computer science. It has always been his very first priority to make his students feel safe, heard, and understood. Though STEM is inherently political as it shapes human rights, never once did Peyrin even allude to his political views during class time, and never once did the quality of his commitment to his teaching falter even during his hunger strike. His suspension for engaging in a hunger strike as a peaceful act of protest against the genocide of the Palestinian people is a profound betrayal of the values UC Berkeley claims to uphold. STEM is not morally neutral. Cloud services, AI systems, and weapons technology, all fields shaped by universities like ours, play a direct role in the violence Palestinians face. Peyrin is one of the few faculty members who has openly asked us to confront that reality, and his courage is exactly what academic spaces should protect, not punish. ​​As the letter states, there are no universities left in Gaza. Hundreds of thousands of Palestinian students have lost years of education, and it is unconscionable for UC Berkeley to claim it is protecting “the rights of all to teaching and learning” while disciplining a lecturer who demanded an end to the destruction of an entire people’s educational future. I am signing because divestment is the bare minimum, and reinstating Peyrin is an urgent necessity. I am signing because I want a university that stands with those who speak for justice, not one that silences them. I am signing because I want to be proud of this institution, and right now, I cannot be unless it corrects this wrong. As a student, I stand unequivocally with Peyrin and with the people of Palestine. We will not be intimidated into silence.
